docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students learn about debates regarding gay rights in the United States following the Supreme Court's Lawrence v. Texas decision. They then participate in a fishbowl discussion to further explore questions on marriage, adoption, custody, employment, and military service as they apply to gays and lesbians.

byline.original: By ANNISSA HAMBOUZ and YASMIN CHIN EISENHAUER

docs.lead_paragraph: According to the official Popular Baby Names Web site, the name we are considering for our daughter, to be born later this summer, was in the Top 200 for her sex last year. It was less popular than Molly but more so than Abby. This has me worried. It seems perched at a precarious point from which it could, without warning, rocket into overuse. Witness Chloe, which has shot from 184 to 24 since 1991. Call out the name in your local Gymboree, and four little heads will whip around. Popular Baby Names, which is operated by the Social Security Administration, ranks the 1,000 most common boys' and girls' names since 1900 (www.ssa.gov/OACT/babynames/). You can also look up a specific name and track its status over time (an activity that, I warn you, is an Internet addict's sinkhole). The site, started seven years ago, was initially the side project of a government actuary named Michael Shackleford. Michael reigned as the No. 1 boys' name for 35 years beginning in 1964, after about a decade of duking it out with David and Robert. It was unseated by Jacob in 1999.

headline.main: Where Have All the Lisas Gone?

docs.abstract: Peggy Orenstein article examines current popular names and how names wax and wane with time and trends; offers list of names predicted to be most popular by 2010 by Pamela Redmond and Linda Rosenkrantz, authors of Beyond Jennifer & Jason, Madison & Montana; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: I am told that it rained for each of the 13 days in June that I rested, on my left side, in my Upper West Side apartment. I heard the patter on my air conditioner, and noticed that no light seemed to be bouncing off the muddy brick walls that are my view from the living room window. Other than that, I have to take everyone's word for it. About 24 weeks into my pregnancy, my doctor concluded that racing up and down subway stairs and coming home to take care of a 4-year-old was not conducive to healthy fetal development. So I was ordered to bed, eight hours a day, for two weeks. I was told I could go out to dinner. Once.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer essay on what it is like being confined to bed rest in a New York apartment during pregnancy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dutch abortion rights activists sailed for home after a two-week protest against Poland's strict antiabortion laws. The Langenort, a tugboat carrying a mobile abortion clinic, left the port of Wladyslawowo after a third daylong voyage into international waters where Dutch physicians said they offered pregnancy counseling and contraception. Polish officials said after earlier trips that seals had been broken on abortion-inducing drugs on the ship and have opened an inquiry. Peter S. Green (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Abortion Boat Sails Away

docs.abstract: Langenort, Dutch ship housing mobile abortion clinic, leaves Wladyslawowo (Poland) after three days of voyages to international waters where Dutch physicians offered counseling and contraception; Polish officials have opened inquiry into violations of strict antiabortion laws, after seals on abortion-inducing drugs on ship were found to be broken (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Wedlock,'' Pilobolus Dance Theater's latest premiere, is a nifty and sophisticated piece about human relations. Presented on Tuesday night in the company's third program at the Joyce Theater, it offered a crash course in psychology through eight terse duets. Unlike many recent Pilobolus pieces, ''Wedlock'' is neither just light nor just dark. Like human relations, it is something in between. Its choreographer, Jonathan Wolken, uses humor to illuminate a painful situation, not to mock it.

headline.main: Like a Horse and Carriage, Harness and All

docs.abstract: Anna Kisselgoff reviews premiere of new work, Wedlock, by Pilobolus Dance Theater; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, just shy of his 16th birthday, Dionisio Martins landed at Kennedy Airport with $20 in his pocket, alone, speaking no English and traumatized by his family's fate in a West African civil war: his uncle and brother had been killed; his mother abducted and not seen since. Uncertain where to go, Mr. Martins stayed at the airport for eight hours, until an African taxi driver took him to a Bronx apartment shared by several West Africans. He stayed with them for several months, worked at a hat factory and eventually found his way to the Manhattan Comprehensive Night and Day High School, an unusual public school that helps older students get back on track after their education has been derailed.

headline.main: LAST CHANCE HIGH: A School for the Unwanted; At School for Hardest Cases, Perseverance, Night and Day

docs.abstract: Last Chance High, special report on Manhattan Comprehensive Night and Day High School, public school that helps older students get back on track after their education has been derailed; unlike most other public schools in New York, night and day school accepts people who are over 17, have history of school troubles, speak little English or otherwise seem unlikely to be able to pass Regents exams and graduate in reasonable amount of time; school goes to great lengths to help its 800 students earn high school diploma; students also get help from nonprofit social service agency, Comprehensive Development Inc, which uses $1 million in private donations to provide tutors, lawyers, social workers and help with anything students might need, like eyeglasses, jobs or place to live; 149 students graduated last week, receiving diplomas that once seemed beyond their reach; some of their stories detailed; photos (L)

docs.section_name: Front Page; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The government should encourage women and girls to reduce the amount of meat, whole milk and other fatty foods they eat as a way of protecting themselves and their offspring from dioxins, harmful residues of natural and industrial combustion, an expert panel said today. A report by the Institute of Medicine, a nonprofit health policy advisory body, recommended that the government do more to educate women and girls about how to limit consumption of dioxins, which can be passed through the placenta to a fetus or through breast milk to an infant.

headline.main: U.S. Urged to Educate Women About Foods Linked to Dioxin

docs.abstract: Institute of Medicine recommends government do more to educate women and girls to cut amount of meat, whole milk and other fatty foods they eat as way of protecting themselves and their offspring from dioxins, pollutants that linger in environment and lodge in fatty tissues of farm animals; dioxins can be passed through placenta to fetus or through breast milk to infant (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Big babies -- nine-pounders and up -- are on the rise. And while it's better for babies to be large than small, newborns over nine pounds face some health concerns of their own, including complications in delivery and higher risk of adult obesity or diabetes. The increase has been noted in a number of countries, but the reasons have been unclear. Now a Danish study released yesterday has linked it to changing habits -- some positive and some not.
docs.abstract: Danish study shows increase in babies weighing over 8.8 pounds at birth and links increase to declines in smoking, drinking and caffeine use by mothers as well as higher pre-pregnancy weight in mothers; higher birth weights increase risk of adult obesity or diabetes; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the Hamptons, Blond and Blonder At the Southampton premiere of ''Legally Blonde 2'' on Saturday night, the only empty seats were next to REESE WITHERSPOON and HOWARD STERN. So we headed for Ms. Witherspoon, sitting on the aisle with Mr. Witherspoon, her husband, RYAN PHILLIPPE, also an actor. She: bright and bubbly and barely showing her five months of pregnancy. He: a bit bored and slightly disoriented, like a husband without a summer blockbuster.

docs.lead_paragraph: Keith Lee Grant and Daniel Tamulonis had been partners for 15 years when Mr. Grant decided their self-focused life was too empty -- that they had much more to give. So eight years ago this interracial New York couple adopted a 2-day-old infant from Arkansas whom they named Isaac. Both dads quickly became adept at diaper changing, middle-of-the-night feeding and all the other challenges of child care.

headline.main: Gay Families Flourish as Acceptance Grows

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column uses book Gay Baby Boom as framework to discuss statistical similarities between families and children raised by straight couples and the growing number of families headed by gay and lesbian couples; book, authored by psychologists and partners Dr Suzanne M Johnson and Dr Elizabeth O'Connor, measures factors such as peer relationships, gender development, intelligence, school performance and sexual orientation, and finds no significant difference in children raised by same-sex parents; holds that there is some evidence that suggests gay parents, possibly because of overcoming numerous obstacles in becoming parents, may raise children better than more traditional families; photo (M)
